articles.headline: Immigration Quandary: A Mother Torn From Her Baby
articles.snippet: A mother’s separation from a breast-feeding child, a U.S. citizen, has prompted changes to immigration guidelines.
articles.abstract: A mother’s separation from a breast-feeding child, a U.S. citizen, has prompted changes to immigration guidelines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal immigration agents were searching a house in Ohio last month when they found a young Honduran woman nursing her baby.

articles.headline: On Strike to Protect the Gains of the Past, With an Eye on the Future
articles.snippet: Do recent walkouts at the auto unions, on Broadway and in Hollywood portend a resurgence of labor, even a new union militancy?
articles.abstract: Do recent walkouts at the auto unions, on Broadway and in Hollywood portend a resurgence of labor, even a new union militancy?
articles.lead_paragraph: Suddenly, it seems, organized labor is flexing its muscles again.

articles.headline: Shopping Bargains Before the First Bite of Turkey
articles.snippet: For all the dour economic predictions, Americans will still mob the malls this holiday shopping season in search of the right gift at the right price. Here’s a guide to five likely trends.
articles.abstract: For all the dour economic predictions, Americans will still mob the malls this holiday shopping season in search of the right gift at the right price. Here’s a guide to five likely trends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yes, the economic outlook is grim.

articles.headline: In U.S. Name Count, Garcias Are Catching Up With Joneses
articles.snippet: Smith is still the most common American surname, but for the first time, two Hispanic names are in the top 10.
articles.abstract: Smith is still the most common American surname, but for the first time, two Hispanic names are in the top 10.
articles.lead_paragraph: Step aside Moore and Taylor. Welcome Garcia and Rodriguez.

articles.headline: Kmart Items Marked Safe Had Lead
articles.snippet: Kmart said that it would remove all jewelry advertised as “lead free” after it was found that some pieces contained high concentrations of the metal.
articles.abstract: Kmart said that it would remove all jewelry advertised as “lead free” after it was found that some pieces contained high concentrations of the metal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kmart said yesterday that it would remove all jewelry advertised as “lead free” from its shelves after workers at lead monitoring programs who tested the pieces found that some actually contained high concentrations of the metal.

articles.headline: Chávez’s Vision Shares Wealth and Centers Power
articles.snippet: Venezuela seems likely to start an extraordinary experiment in centralized, oil-fueled socialism.
articles.abstract: Venezuela seems likely to start an extraordinary experiment in centralized, oil-fueled socialism.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 16 — In two weeks, Venezuela seems likely to start an extraordinary experiment in centralized, oil-fueled socialism. By law, the workday would be cut to six hours. Street vendors, homemakers and maids would have state-mandated pensions. And President Hugo Chávez would have significantly enhanced powers and be eligible for re-election for the rest of his life.

articles.headline: Forget Fair; It’s Litigation as Usual
articles.snippet: Is a mass tort really the right mechanism to settle disputes about product safety, or to punish corporate wrongdoing?
articles.abstract: Is a mass tort really the right mechanism to settle disputes about product safety, or to punish corporate wrongdoing?
articles.lead_paragraph: They had the kits ready to go. The “trial package,” they called it.

articles.headline: Brothers, Bad Blood and the Blackwater Tangle
articles.snippet: A story of two brothers with ties to the security contractor involves estrangement and a potential conflict of interest.
articles.abstract: A story of two brothers with ties to the security contractor involves estrangement and a potential conflict of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 — They were smart, scrappy brothers who rose from modest circumstances in Baltimore to become lacrosse stars at Princeton, succeed in business and land big government jobs.

articles.headline: My Genome, Myself: Seeking Clues in DNA
articles.snippet: For as little as $1,000 and a saliva sample, customers of an infant industry will be able to learn what is known about how their biological code shapes who they are.
articles.abstract: For as little as $1,000 and a saliva sample, customers of an infant industry will be able to learn what is known about how their biological code shapes who they are.
articles.lead_paragraph: The exploration of the human genome has long been relegated to elite scientists in research laboratories. But that is about to change. An infant industry is capitalizing on the plunging cost of genetic testing technology to offer any individual unprecedented — and unmediated — entree to their own DNA.

articles.headline: Discontented, DreamWorks Is in Talks to Join NBC
articles.snippet: Although NBC Universal is interested in striking a deal, it wants DreamWorks to find outside financing to make its movies, which Universal could then distribute.
articles.abstract: Although NBC Universal is interested in striking a deal, it wants DreamWorks to find outside financing to make its movies, which Universal could then distribute.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 — Seeking a way out of an acrimonious relationship at Paramount, the DreamWorks principals — two Hollywood heavyweights, David Geffen and Steven Spielberg — have been negotiating to move their operation to NBC Universal, according to people close to the talks. But negotiations have hit a wall over financing.
articles.byline: By Sharon Waxman and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: The Lottery Industry’s Own Powerball
articles.snippet: Rebecca Paul Hargrove has built multibillion-dollar lotteries that have helped fuel the industry’s growth.
articles.abstract: Rebecca Paul Hargrove has built multibillion-dollar lotteries that have helped fuel the industry’s growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANDING recently in a Knoxville stadium filled with roaring University of Tennessee football fans, Rebecca Paul Hargrove, the highflying impresario of legalized gambling, proudly waved a symbolic check for a billion dollars. The moment, captured on jumbo screens across the stadium, was among the countless plugs for the fund-raising prowess of Tennessee’s lottery, which Ms. Hargrove started four years ago.

articles.headline: Blowing the Whistle, Many Times
articles.snippet: The claim that medical sales practices are draining millions of dollars from public programs is key to what could be one of the largest whistle-blower lawsuits on record.
articles.abstract: The claim that medical sales practices are draining millions of dollars from public programs is key to what could be one of the largest whistle-blower lawsuits on record.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Cynthia Fitzgerald started out in pharmaceutical sales 20 years ago, she received ample training on the right and wrong ways to sell medical products. Right was selling on the merits. Wrong was luring customers with perks and freebies. It was O.K. to buy doctors lunch or dinner, for example, but tempting them with lavish gifts was taboo.

articles.headline: In Korea, a Boot Camp Cure for Web Obsession
articles.snippet: In South Korea, which boasts of its wired society, a camp to treat cyberspace addiction may be a first.
articles.abstract: In South Korea, which boasts of its wired society, a camp to treat cyberspace addiction may be a first.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOKCHEON, South Korea — The compound — part boot camp, part rehab center — resembles programs around the world for troubled youths. Drill instructors drive young men through military-style obstacle courses, counselors lead group sessions, and there are even therapeutic workshops on pottery and drumming.

articles.headline: Does Death Penalty Save Lives? A New Debate
articles.snippet: Studies indicating that executions are a deterrent against future murders have been the subject of sharp criticism.
articles.abstract: Studies indicating that executions are a deterrent against future murders have been the subject of sharp criticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in a generation, the question of whether the death penalty deters murders has captured the attention of scholars in law and economics, setting off an intense new debate about one of the central justifications for capital punishment.

articles.headline: As Owners Feel Mortgage Pain, So Do Renters
articles.snippet: In the growing foreclosure crisis, thousands of families who rent their homes face eviction when owners default on their mortgages.
articles.abstract: In the growing foreclosure crisis, thousands of families who rent their homes face eviction when owners default on their mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In the foreclosure crisis of 2007, thousands of American families are losing their homes without ever missing a payment. They are renters in houses whose owners default on their mortgages — a large but little noticed class of casualties.

articles.headline: Creative Loans, Creative Compensation
articles.snippet: Executives at NovaStar Financial, a subprime mortgage originator whose stock has dropped from $40 to $1.72, have pocketed millions in compensation.
articles.abstract: Executives at NovaStar Financial, a subprime mortgage originator whose stock has dropped from $40 to $1.72, have pocketed millions in compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: THINGS aren’t going very swimmingly for investors in NovaStar Financial, a subprime mortgage originator in Kansas City, Mo. Its stock plummeted last week on news that the company lost $64.05 a share in the third quarter, that it had canceled its preferred stock dividend and that it was no longer able to reap the tax advantages of a real estate investment trust status.

articles.headline: Goldman Sachs Rakes In Profit in Credit Crisis
articles.snippet: Rarely on Wall Street, where money travels in herds, has one firm gotten it so right when nearly everyone else was getting it so wrong.
articles.abstract: Rarely on Wall Street, where money travels in herds, has one firm gotten it so right when nearly everyone else was getting it so wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than three months, as turmoil in the credit market has swept wildly through Wall Street, one mighty investment bank after another has been brought to its knees, leveled by multibillion-dollar blows to their bottom lines.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Creativity, Strikes and Power
articles.snippet: With the ability to darken theaters, the stagehands have what the writers lack: actual leverage.
articles.abstract: With the ability to darken theaters, the stagehands have what the writers lack: actual leverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a good weekend for the labor that is organized around the creative arts.

articles.headline: Chinese Dam Projects Criticized for Their Human Costs
articles.snippet: A year after the completion of the Three Gorges Dam, water pollution, landslides and mass resettlement have led to questions about hydropower as a solution to China’s energy conundrum.
articles.abstract: A year after the completion of the Three Gorges Dam, water pollution, landslides and mass resettlement have led to questions about hydropower as a solution to China’s energy conundrum.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIANMIN VILLAGE, China — Last year, Chinese officials celebrated the completion of the Three Gorges Dam by releasing a list of 10 world records. As in: The Three Gorges is the world’s biggest dam, biggest power plant and biggest consumer of dirt, stone, concrete and steel. Ever. Even the project’s official tally of 1.13 million displaced people made the list as record No. 10.

articles.headline: Financials, Once a Balm, Now Hamper the Market
articles.snippet: Many market specialists expect that financial stocks will remain under pressure in the coming year, making it harder for the broader market to regain its footing.
articles.abstract: Many market specialists expect that financial stocks will remain under pressure in the coming year, making it harder for the broader market to regain its footing.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the air came out of the technology and telecommunications bubble this decade, the stock market found a new champion in the financial sector.

articles.headline: Hollywood Producer of Varied Interests, Many Hits, but Little Fame
articles.snippet: Brian Grazer is one of the most successful producers in Hollywood, but his public profile remains relatively slight when compared with his Hollywood peers.
articles.abstract: Brian Grazer is one of the most successful producers in Hollywood, but his public profile remains relatively slight when compared with his Hollywood peers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Brian Grazer, one of the most successful producers in Hollywood, would seem to be a memorable guest, with his energetic manner and elaborately spiked hair. But to make sure he is not forgotten, he will often leave behind a small photo of himself in an inexpensive heart-shaped frame after attending a dinner or party, hiding it among his host’s family photographs.

articles.headline: A Guerrilla Video Site Meets MTV
articles.snippet: Vice magazine, known for a raw, ironic sensibility, risqué photographs and a willingness to deal in taboo subjects, is now giving Viacom a lab for Web programming.
articles.abstract: Vice magazine, known for a raw, ironic sensibility, risqué photographs and a willingness to deal in taboo subjects, is now giving Viacom a lab for Web programming.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vice magazine has built a small media empire out of a raw, ironic sensibility, risqué photographs and a willingness to deal in taboo subjects.

articles.headline: Child Matadors Draw Olés in Mexico’s Bullrings
articles.snippet: Mexico’s mini-matadors are drawing ever larger crowds as well as criticism from those who say they should find a safer extracurricular activity.
articles.abstract: Mexico’s mini-matadors are drawing ever larger crowds as well as criticism from those who say they should find a safer extracurricular activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: MÉRIDA, Mexico — Michelito Lagravere Peniche, 9, put his fingers to his head to create mock horns and charged at Jairo Miguel, 14, who gracefully dodged him on the first pass. But Michelito was an aggressive bull and he circled back, this time striking his friend Jairo in the leg. Both boys erupted in laughter.

articles.headline: U.S. Says Attacks in Iraq Fell to Feb. 2006 Level
articles.snippet: New U.S. military data showed that attacks had declined to the lowest level since January 2006. It is the third week in a row that attacks have been at this reduced level.
articles.abstract: New U.S. military data showed that attacks had declined to the lowest level since January 2006. It is the third week in a row that attacks have been at this reduced level.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Nov. 18 — The American military said Sunday that the weekly number of attacks in Iraq had fallen to the lowest level since just before the February 2006 bombing of the Shiite shrine in Samarra, an event commonly used as a benchmark for the country’s worst spasm of bloodletting after the American invasion nearly five years ago.
articles.byline: By Cara Buckley and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Critics Assail Weak Dollar at OPEC Event
articles.snippet: A meeting of the heads of state of the OPEC countries ended on a political note, with two leaders  blaming the weakness of the U.S. dollar for high oil prices.
articles.abstract: A meeting of the heads of state of the OPEC countries ended on a political note, with two leaders  blaming the weakness of the U.S. dollar for high oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 18 — A rare meeting of the heads of state of the OPEC countries ended here today on a political note, with two leaders — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela and President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran — blaming the weakness of the United States dollar for high oil prices.
